small_mag: Diffusely infiltrating tumor cells disrupting normal breast architecture.
Areas of necrosis surrounded by neoplastic cells.
Tubule-like structures formed by tumor cells in certain areas.
Foci of microcalcification within the tumor mass.
Areas of desmoplasia indicative of stromal reaction.
Tumor cells invading into the surrounding adipose tissue.
Presence of lymphovascular invasion by tumor cells.
Disorganized pattern of cell growth compared to normal ducts.
Areas with DCIS transition into IDC, illustrating disease progression.
Focal areas of hemorrhage within the tumor.
big_mag: Pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli, indicative of high-grade malignancy.
Mitotic figures, suggesting rapid cell division and tumor growth.
Areas of comedonecrosis, characterized by central tumor necrosis.
Intracellular and extracellular mucin production.
Irregularly shaped, distorted tumor glands.
High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, with scant cytoplasm in tumor cells.
Presence of lymphovascular invasion, with tumor cells in vascular spaces.
Perineural invasion, with tumor cells surrounding nerve structures.
Basement membrane disruption, indicative of invasive growth.
Presence of signet-ring cells, a variant of invasive ductal carcinoma.
Varying degrees of tumor differentiation, with poorly differentiated areas more likely to be high-grade.
Presence of intraductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) components.
Fibrotic response in the surrounding stroma.
Presence of inflammatory infiltrates, such as lymphocytes and macrophages.
Formation of tumor emboli in lymphatic or vascular channels.
Desmoplastic reaction, characterized by collagen-rich stromal response.
Multiple nucleoli within a single cell, suggesting high-grade malignancy.
Apoptotic bodies, indicative of cell death.
Signs of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in tumor cells.
Cellular budding, with single cells or small clusters of cells breaking away from the main tumor.
Presence of tumor giant cells, a variant of invasive ductal carcinoma.
Eosinophilic cytoplasm in some tumor cells.
Presence of Paget's cells in the epidermis.
Intracytoplasmic lumina, which appear as small, clear spaces within tumor cells.
Tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, indicative of high-grade malignancy.
Lipid-filled vacuoles within some tumor cells.
Areas of squamous differentiation, a variant of invasive ductal carcinoma.
Presence of hyalinization, characterized by the formation of hard, glassy areas.
Tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, suggestive of an immune response.
Presence of central fibrosis, characterized by the formation of fibrous tissue within the tumor.

small_mag: Linear, diffuse infiltration pattern with no defined tumor mass.
Infiltration of tumor cells into pre-existing breast tissue, causing thickening.
Invasion of adjacent adipose tissue by carcinoma cells.
Lack of desmoplastic reaction in the surrounding stroma.
Absence of significant necrosis or comedonecrosis.
Presence of targetoid features, with tumor cells surrounding normal ducts and lobules.
Expansion of the lobules by monotonous small cells.
Pattern of single-file cells that permeate through tissue in a linear manner.
Presence of multifocality, with several distinct areas of cancer spread.
Tumor cells may insinuate through collagenous stroma without disrupting its architecture.
big_mag: Uniform, small tumor cells with minimal pleomorphism.
Round or ovoid nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli.
Absence or lack of prominent mitotic activity.
Intracytoplasmic lumen, containing eosinophilic secretions.
Single-file linear arrangement of tumor cells.
Signet ring cells, filled with mucin, pushing the nucleus to one side.
Cells often lack E-cadherin expression, contributing to their discohesive nature.
Perineural invasion, with tumor cells surrounding nerve structures.
Tumor cells invading in a concentric manner around ducts and lobules.
Indian file pattern - elongated chains of cells following the lines of collagen.
Lack of associated ductal carcinoma in situ.
Presence of lymphocytic infiltrate, especially near the invasive edges.
Presence of an occasional rosette-like structure.
Tumor cells may exhibit a targetoid arrangement around ducts and lobules.
Loss of basement membrane, indicative of invasive growth.
Tumor cells can be seen infiltrating adipose tissue.
Presence of histiocytic giant cells.
Occasional presence of a clear cytoplasm in tumor cells.
No surrounding reactive stroma seen.
Focal areas of intracellular and extracellular mucin.
Sparse cytoplasm in tumor cells.
Invasive margins of the lobules can be irregular.
The nuclei of tumor cells can show a moderate degree of variation in size and shape.
Occasional presence of inflammatory infiltrate.
Lobular carcinoma in situ may be present adjacent to invasive carcinoma.
Presence of microcalcifications.
Fibrosis may be seen in the surrounding breast tissue.
Some cells may show a moderate amount of cytoplasmic eosinophilia.
Tumor cells may show a lack of cohesion, indicative of a loss of cell-cell adhesion.
Presence of pagetoid spread within the ductal epithelium.
